A STIMULATING ASSEMBLY
From time to time, during the past few years, "feature"
programs have been arranged for the weekly Assemblies.
Prominent men have been secured a long .time in advance,
and each important event has been heralded at great length
in the News-Letter. Interesting as some of these Assemblies
have been, none could surpass that of last Thursday, a hurriedly arranged affair, with Dr. Mitchell and members of the
Hopkins "Y" on different sides of the fence.
The program was interesting; it was stimulating. For
the first time in four years questions from the floor showed
that the audience was not only listening, but thinking. At
noon the Barn was filled with the buzzing of interested discussion and argument. Contrary to innumerable articles in
recent magazines, it seemed that the brain of the college student was not dormant. We trust there will be more such Assemblies to keep it awake in the future.

"A DEFINITE PLACE"
Each day, as the midyear examinations draw nearer and
nearer, the word "study" assumes a greater importance in our
mind. This very uncomfortable mental condition leads us
quite naturally to the consideration of another subject, which
by Way of contrast is not in the least unpleasant—the study
rooms,which are being prepared on the fourth floor of Gilman
These study rooms fill the traditional and time-honored
"long felt need"; we might go so far as to use one of our own
favorite expressions, which seems to call forth a great amount
of unseemly glee from the leading literary lights of the college, and say that the rooms will have a "definite place on
the campus."
Seriously speaking, however, we are glad that when the
Psychology Department moved their dangerous looking equipment to a place where they can carry out their experiments
on mice and men with greater freedom, some of the space will
be used for study rooms. They will be a great help to those
who wish to study on the University grounds. At present the
Library is entirely too overcrowded, but there is nowhere else
to go. Vacant classrooms are unsatisfactory, while the Barn
is out of the question. If you go downstairs someone will
walk on your feet or spill food on your book; upstairs some
enthusiastic soul will invariably be banging on the piano, and
as soon as his noise ceases, the band troops in for a rehearsal.
It is unfair, however, to criticise the Barn on this score, for
we must not forget that it is our Student Activities Building.
and center of student life.
The rooms in Gilman Hall should go a long way toward
solving the problem. We have one word of caution, however. It May be qtat when the rooms are opened they may
be so attractive that undergraduates in their great joy will
forget that they are for study. That would be a fatal error.
We understand that. when the space was left vacant it was in
great demand, and that it was secured for the undergraduates
only with the understanding that the rooms should be only
for study. To lose sight of this fact too far might serve to
put conditions back to their present state.

Brother Brint Stone the other day.
Brother Brint agreed with us but at
the same time seemed to think that
if the sort of violation mentioned at
the beginning of this column does
exist, there is very little that can be
done about it. And that's where we
disagree with Brother Brint.
We have enough confidence in
Hopkins men to believe that the
mere mention of this condition will
alleviate it. After all, the question
of how broadly the student body
Wishes to interpret the provisions of
the honor system rests with each individual student.

And in the last analysis, the
Honor System places absolutely no
inhibitions upon one, but allows
Hopkins men a degree of freedom
enjoyed by students of very few
Other colleges.

HILL HAS SAVED FORTYTWO LIVES
Continued from Page 1, Col. 3
enlisted in the Navy in June, 1917.
He disembarked in France with a
land force on Christmas Eve of that
year, and was very seriously
wounded in action two weeks later.
A shell fragment carried away a
large part of the right side of his
skull, which is now covered only by
skin and hair grafted over the
wound. He did not recover full
possession of his senses for over a
year after receiving the injury. For
a long time he was unable to regain
his health. Many of the doctors
who examined him predicted his
death as only a matter of a short
time. In 1924 local papers came
out with headlines that Hill was
pronounced dying. On the records
of the War Department he is still
listed as permanently and totally
disabled. But today he is to all appearances the picture of health.
Good Season Last Year

Last year he proved his ability
by whipping the Hopkins swimming team in two weeks into such
shape that they won every meet
thereafter, losing only the first meet
to Rutgers' chativionship team,
which was met the week following
mid-year examinations, when the
team had been together only three
days.
During the war, before going
overseas Hill received a special citation from Assistant Secretary of
the Navy Roosevelt. This was on
the occasion when he dove from
the top deck of the Leviathan to
save a man drowning in the icy
waters of the Hudson fifty feet below. The man had leaped from a
burning lighter that was only ten
feet away from the Leviathan. He
could not swim, but preferred to
drown than to burn to death. Hill
only saved himself from landing on
the deck of the lighter by grabbing
a loose rope hanging from the great
liner. Although he burnt the skin
off of both hands, he fell into the
water and effected the rescue.

An independent engineering organization
recently made a survey of fuel costs in the
plant of a nationally-known company that
had changed over to gas, for a large part of
ofits production eighteen months previously.'
The following quotations, taken directly
from the engineer's report, show some of
the advantages effected in this plant through
the use of gas:
"Cost reduced 28%"
"Annual saving $3,676.32"
"Net yearly return of 102% on investment"
"Gas more dependable"
"Faster heating"

A STIMULATING ASSEMBLY
From time to time, during the past few years, "feature"
programs have been arranged for the weekly Assemblies.
Prominent men have been secured a long .time in advance,
and each important event has been heralded at great length
in the News-Letter. Interesting as some of these Assemblies
have been, none could surpass that of last Thursday, a hurriedly arranged affair, with Dr. Mitchell and members of the
Hopkins "Y" on different sides of the fence.
The program was interesting; it was stimulating. For
the first time in four years questions from the floor showed
that the audience was not only listening, but thinking. At
noon the Barn was filled with the buzzing of interested discussion and argument. Contrary to innumerable articles in
recent magazines, it seemed that the brain of the college student was not dormant. We trust there will be more such Assemblies to keep it awake in the future.

"A DEFINITE PLACE"
Each day, as the midyear examinations draw nearer and
nearer, the word "study" assumes a greater importance in our
mind. This very uncomfortable mental condition leads us
quite naturally to the consideration of another subject, which
by Way of contrast is not in the least unpleasant—the study
rooms,which are being prepared on the fourth floor of Gilman
These study rooms fill the traditional and time-honored
"long felt need"; we might go so far as to use one of our own
favorite expressions, which seems to call forth a great amount
of unseemly glee from the leading literary lights of the college, and say that the rooms will have a "definite place on
the campus."
Seriously speaking, however, we are glad that when the
Psychology Department moved their dangerous looking equipment to a place where they can carry out their experiments
on mice and men with greater freedom, some of the space will
be used for study rooms. They will be a great help to those
who wish to study on the University grounds. At present the
Library is entirely too overcrowded, but there is nowhere else
to go. Vacant classrooms are unsatisfactory, while the Barn
is out of the question. If you go downstairs someone will
walk on your feet or spill food on your book; upstairs some
enthusiastic soul will invariably be banging on the piano, and
as soon as his noise ceases, the band troops in for a rehearsal.
It is unfair, however, to criticise the Barn on this score, for
we must not forget that it is our Student Activities Building.
and center of student life.
The rooms in Gilman Hall should go a long way toward
solving the problem. We have one word of caution, however. It May be qtat when the rooms are opened they may
be so attractive that undergraduates in their great joy will
forget that they are for study. That would be a fatal error.
We understand that. when the space was left vacant it was in
great demand, and that it was secured for the undergraduates
only with the understanding that the rooms should be only
for study. To lose sight of this fact too far might serve to
put conditions back to their present state.

Robert S. Nyburg as Junior Editor.

the honor system rests with each individual student.

inhibitions upon one, but allows

HILL HAS SAVED FORTYTWO LIVES
Continued from Page 1, Col. 3
enlisted in the Navy in June, 1917.
He disembarked in France with a
land force on Christmas Eve of that
year, and was very seriously
wounded in action two weeks later.
A shell fragment carried away a
large part of the right side of his
skull, which is now covered only by
skin and hair grafted over the
wound. He did not recover full
possession of his senses for over a
year after receiving the injury. For
a long time he was unable to regain
his health. Many of the doctors
who examined him predicted his
death as only a matter of a short
time. In 1924 local papers came
out with headlines that Hill was
pronounced dying. On the records
of the War Department he is still
listed as permanently and totally
disabled. But today he is to all appearances the picture of health.
Good Season Last Year

Last year he proved his ability
by whipping the Hopkins swimming team in two weeks into such
shape that they won every meet
thereafter, losing only the first meet
to Rutgers' chativionship team,
which was met the week following
mid-year examinations, when the
team had been together only three
days.
During the war, before going
overseas Hill received a special citation from Assistant Secretary of
the Navy Roosevelt. This was on
the occasion when he dove from
the top deck of the Leviathan to
save a man drowning in the icy
waters of the Hudson fifty feet below. The man had leaped from a
burning lighter that was only ten
feet away from the Leviathan. He
could not swim, but preferred to
drown than to burn to death. Hill
only saved himself from landing on
the deck of the lighter by grabbing
a loose rope hanging from the great
liner. Although he burnt the skin
off of both hands, he fell into the
water and effected the rescue.
